channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Updates: As Ukraine and Russia Prepare to Talk, Fighting Rages On
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky agreed to send a delegation to discuss an end to the conflict, but said he feared Monday’s talks would not result in peace as Russian forces massed outside Kyiv and the value of ruble plummeted overnight.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: Civilian volunteers sorted empty bottles to be used for Molotov cocktails in a parking lot in Dnipro, Ukraine, on Sunday.

item.title: Ties That Bind Putin and Xi Tested by Russia's Ukraine Invasion
item.description: The two autocrats have brought their countries closer together than ever. But for China, the costs of Russia’s adventurism could be high.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Alexei Druzhinin
item.media:description: Xi Jinping, China’s leader, and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, at the Bolshoi Theater in Moscow in 2019. Mr. Xi called Mr. Putin his “best friend” during that visit.

item.title: ‘Rain Bomb’ Hits Northeastern Australia, Killing at Least 8
item.description: Days of downpours have pummeled Queensland and New South Wales, with the authorities describing the wild weather as “waves of water just coming down.”
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Jason O'Brien/Australian Associated Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Using small boats to travel through floodwaters in Lismore, Australia, on Monday.

item.title: Brazil, Land of the Thong, Embraces Its Heavier Self
item.description: A country known for beach bodies is confronting soaring obesity rates with new laws that enshrine protections for people who are overweight.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Dado Galdieri
item.media:description: Mariana Donato, 36, taking a break from her dance classes in Recife, Brazil. She and her dance troupe gathered to rehearse ahead of the Miss Plus Size Fashion pageant in Recife, where they performed routines that challenge thin beauty standards.

item.title: Why the Chinese Internet Is Cheering Russia’s Invasion
item.description: As the world overwhelmingly condemns the assault on Ukraine, online opinion in China is mostly pro-Russia, pro-war and pro-Putin.
item.dc:creator: Li Yuan
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: A bombed Ukrainian home in south Kyiv. Many Chinese social media users have praised President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and accepted his justification for invading Ukraine.

item.title: North Korea Launches a Ballistic Missile, South Korea Says
item.description: Flight data suggested that the missile launched Sunday was less powerful than the last one the North tested, four weeks ago.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Ahn Young-Joon/Associated Press
item.media:description: Watching news coverage of a North Korean missile launch in Seoul last month.

item.title: Russia's War With Ukraine Is Already Costing Russian Economy
item.description: Despite the Kremlin’s efforts to obscure the offensive in Ukraine, the costs of the war were already evident in both economic and social turmoil.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Walking past Red Square in Moscow on Saturday.

item.title: Putin’s Aggression Leaves His Right-Wing Fan Club Squirming
item.description: The Russian strongman has for years been idolized by a Who’s Who of populist, nationalist leaders. They are now stumbling over what to say.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Mikhail Klimentyev/Sputnik, via Reuters
item.media:description: Marine Le Pen, the leader of the far-right National Rally party, met President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in Moscow in 2017.

item.title: New Amazon Headquarters Sparks Feud Among Indigenous South Africans
item.description: The development, still under construction, sits on sacred land in Cape Town. But some Indigenous leaders have allied with the developers, prompting a debate over who speaks for First Nations people.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:credit: Joao Silva/The New York Times
item.media:description: A 37-acre site in Cape Town, on which Amazon is developing its African headquarters, is widely believed to lie in the area where Indigenous South Africans first fought colonial invaders.

item.title: At the Polish Border, Tens of Thousands of Ukrainian Refugees
item.description: They have been warmly welcomed in a country whose border guards last year beat back mostly Afghan and Middle Eastern migrants with batons.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: Olha Zapotochna with her gravely ill son, Arthur, after crossing the Ukrainian-Polish border on Friday. “We are still living in the 21st century, I hope,” Ms. Zapotochna said.

item.title: ‘Abrupt Changes’: China Caught in a Bind Over Russia’s Invasion of Ukraine
item.description: China has presented itself as a defender of sovereign independence. But its reluctance to denounce Russia’s aggression forces it into an awkward position.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Alexei Druzhinin
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia meeting with his Chinese counterpart, Xi Jinping, this month in Beijing.

item.title: 8 Found Dead After Ferry Fire Off Greece as Grim Search Continues
item.description: The blaze aboard the Euroferry Olympia burned for most of a week. Hundreds of passengers were rescued, but at least three more are believed missing.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:credit: Angelos Tzortzinis/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Euroferry Olympia near the Greek island of Corfu on Tuesday. Fire broke out aboard on Feb. 18.

item.title: In Video, a Defiant President Zelensky Says, ‘We Are Here’
item.description: The 44-year-old president of Ukraine videotaped himself in Kyiv as Russian forces closed in on the capital, vowing to fight them to the end.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Ukraine Presidency, via AFP/— Getty Imagess
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky early Friday in Kyiv, in a photo provided by Ukraine’s government.

item.title: The Ruble Dropped to Record Levels Against Dollar
item.description: The ruble dropped to record lows against the dollar, stirring fears of inflation and bank runs, and the central bank raised a key interest rate sharply.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: People lined up to get cash from an A.T.M. in a mall in Moscow on Sunday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Russia’s nuclear forces on alert.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Ukrainian flag being raised over a newly-established checkpoint on Sunday in Hushchyntsi, Ukraine.

item.title: Why Kyrie Irving Still Won’t Play in Brooklyn if Some Covid Restrictions End Next Week
item.description: Barclays Center would remain under a private sector vaccine mandate that took effect in December.
item.dc:creator: Sopan Deb
item.media:credit: Benny Sieu/USA Today Sports, via Reuters
item.media:description: Kyrie Irving, left, in a game in Milwaukee on Saturday. He has played in only 15 of the Nets’ 61 games, in part because of his refusal to be vaccinated.

item.title: Capitol's Mask Mandate Being Lifted in Time for State of the Union
item.description: This year’s address from the president is open to all members of Congress.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Weisman
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: The mask mandate on the House floor at the U.S. Capitol is being lifted.

item.title: Putin Declares a Nuclear Alert, and Biden Seeks De-escalation
item.description: When the Russian leader ordered his nuclear forces into “special combat readiness,” the U.S. could have gone on high alert. Instead, the administration tried not to inflame him.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and William J. Broad
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Svetlana Akimova, 82, sheltered in a parking garage in Kyiv on Saturday as heavy fighting took place outside her apartment building.

item.title: In Foreign Policy U-turn, Germany Ups Military Spending, Arms Ukraine
item.description: Germany agrees to strengthen its military in the latest foreign policy about-face, amid pressure from allies and horror at Russia’s attack on Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:credit: Gregor Fischer/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The German army’s barracks in Munster earlier this month.

item.title: Pyeongchang Still Awaits Its Olympic Payoff
item.description: One of South Korea’s poorest regions hoped that hosting the 2018 Games would bring tourists and prosperity. It hasn’t really happened.
item.dc:creator: Kelly Kasulis Cho
item.media:credit: Tim Franco for The New York Times
item.media:description: A reminder of the 2018 Winter Olympics in Gangneung, South Korea, which hosted some of the events.

item.title: Ukraine Agrees to Talks With Russia, but Fighting Still Rages
item.description: Putin, accusing the West of “aggressive statements,” puts nuclear forces on alert. Kyiv remains in Russian cross-hairs as Ukrainians push back.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins, Anton Troianovski and Steven Erlanger

item.title: War in Ukraine Forces Israel Into a Delicate Balancing Act
item.description: Israel is a strong ally of the United States, and its leaders have a good relationship with Volodymyr Zelensky, Ukraine’s Jewish president. But Israel also doesn’t want to provoke Russia.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Isabel Kershner and Ronen Bergman
item.media:credit: Oded Balilty/Associated Press
item.media:description: Pro-Ukraine demonstrators outside the Russian Embassy in Tel Aviv on Thursday, after Russian troops attacked Ukraine.

item.title: Ukrainian Citizens Prepare to Fight Russian Army
item.description: In cities and towns in Central Ukraine that have not yet heard the boom of Russian artillery fire, residents spent the weekend preparing furiously for the possibly of an attack.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: Civilian volunteers in Dnipro organize and pack donations for distribution, and load empty bottles to be used for Molotov cocktails from a collection point on Sunday.

item.title: Ukrainians in Britain Take Up the Cause Back Home
item.description: Whether vowing to kill Russians or offering medical supplies, Ukrainian citizens are too impatient to sit idly by.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oleksandr Bilyy, a deliveryman living in Britain, drove for two days hoping to join the fight for Ukraine. “Nothing will change if I stay in my house,” he said.

item.title: Ukraine War Forces Hungary’s Orban Into Political Contortions
item.description: The pro-Russia, anti-immigrant Hungarian prime minister, who denounced any sanctions against Russia just weeks ago, has been forced to reverse himself as an election looms.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Novak
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Several hundred people who fled Ukraine huddled in small groups on Sunday at the train station in Zahony, Hungary, trying to figure out their next move.

item.title: EU Will Ask States to Grant Asylum to Ukrainian Refugees for Up to 3 Years
item.description: More than 300,000 people have fled into the European Union since Russia invaded Ukraine on Thursday, the bloc said, and it is expecting millions more.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: People crossing from Ukraine into Hungary at the border in Zahony on Sunday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Ukraine Agrees to Talks
item.description: Plus new research into the pandemic’s origins and North Korea’s latest missile test.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Katya, 25, sits with her mother, Oleksandre, 50, in a shelter in a gymnasium in Kyiv, Ukraine, February 26, 2022.

item.title: New York Ends Its Mask Mandate for Schools
item.description: Gov. Kathy Hochul said the statewide mask mandate in schools would end on Wednesday, and Mayor Eric Adams planned to lift pandemic measures in the city on March 7.
item.dc:creator: Grace Ashford, Eliza Shapiro and Emma G. Fitzsimmons
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Natalie Keyssar for The New York Times
item.media:description: An elementary school in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, last month. Mayor Eric Adams said on Sunday that school mask mandates will likely end on March 7 in New York City.

item.title: Once Sleepy and Picturesque, Ukrainian Villages Mobilize for War
item.description: While Russian assaults on Ukrainian cities have drawn most of the attention in the war’s early days, civilians in country towns have joined the fight, putting aside the routines of daily village life.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Ukrainian flag being raised over a newly-established checkpoint on Sunday in Hushchyntsi, Ukraine.

item.title: How Zelensky Rallied Ukrainians, and the World, Against Putin
item.description: Mr. Zelensky’s decision to remain in the capital, Kyiv, while it’s under Russian attack has moved many.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Volodymyr Zelensky, via Facebook
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky has made effective use of social media throughout his candidacy and presidency.

item.title: Memo from antsy executives: Plans to return to in-person work are real this time.
item.dc:creator: Emma Goldberg
item.media:credit: Jeenah Moon for The New York Times
item.media:description: TIAA Financial Services in Manhattan is targeting March 7 for employees to return to the office.

item.title: US Deflects Putin’s Nuclear Alert as Another Effort at Escalation
item.description: Both countries have various levels of alert, and it was unclear how Putin’s wording would be implemented by Russian nuclear forces.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:credit: Leah Millis/Reuters
item.media:description: A White House military aide boarding Marine One with the “nuclear football” that followed President Biden to Delaware on Friday.

item.title: Brick-and-mortar stores staged a comeback in 2021.
item.dc:creator: Shira Ovide

item.title: 2-for-1 ticket deals and other offers aim to lure New Yorkers back to the arts.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens
item.media:credit: Nina Westervelt for The New York Times
item.media:description: Anna Lee Hirschi, left, and Christa Chiao toasted each other with their two-for-one proseccos at the Metropolitan Museum of Art recently.

item.title: Liz Truss Says She Would Support Britons Fighting for Ukraine
item.description: Britain’s foreign secretary said people should “absolutely” go to Ukraine and fight “if that is what they want do to.”
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Leon Neal/Getty Images
item.media:description: Anti-war demonstrators outside the Russian Embassy in London on Sunday.

item.title: Germany Announces Increase in Defense Spending Amid Russia's Ukraine Invasion
item.description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz announced a major increase to Germany’s defense budget, a shift in longstanding policy.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Michele Tantussi/Reuters
item.media:description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany addressing lawmakers in Berlin on Sunday.

item.title: More Countries Close Airspace to Russian Planes Over Ukraine Invasion
item.description: The E.U. and Canada barred Russian planes in response to the invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Sergei Ilnitsky/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Aeroflot planes in Moscow last year. The Russian carrier’s flights have been banned, along with other Russian aircraft, from the airspace of a growing number of countries.

item.title: Putin vs. Democracy
item.description: Democracy is on the decline worldwide, and Vladimir Putin is a big factor.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: A burning power station in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: South Korea Records Deadliest Day of Pandemic
item.description: A grim milestone is reached a few days after the nation topped 170,000 new cases in a single day.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:credit: Ryu Hyung-Seok/Yonhap, via Associated Press
item.media:description: People waiting in line at a coronavirus testing site in Seoul on Saturday.

item.title: ‘I Just Want to Live in Our Country’: Civilians Join the Fight in Kyiv
item.description: Julia, a teacher and Ukrainian volunteer, wept as she waited to be deployed to fight Russian troops around Kyiv on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: Andriy Dubchak and Dmitriy Khavin
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Julia, a teacher and Ukrainian volunteer, wept as she waited to be deployed to fight Russian troops around Kyiv on Saturday.

item.title: Ukrainians escape to neighboring Poland.
item.dc:creator: Maciek Nabrdalik and Mauricio Lima
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times

item.title: Putin’s Critics Call for Boycotts of Russian Vodka
item.description: The governors of New Hampshire and Ohio announced measures aimed halting the sales of Russian-made and Russian-branded spirits.
item.dc:creator: Azi Paybarah
item.category: Virginia Department of Alcoholic Beverage Control
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: The alcohol department at a supermarket in Moscow. In some parts of the United States and other countries, officials are removing Russian vodka from shelves.

item.title: Putin Seems to Sideline Advisers on Ukraine, Taking a Political Risk
item.description: Authoritarian leaders rely on elite support to govern. Jeopardizing those relationships in wartime could be risky, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Alexei Nikolsky
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin leading a Security Council meeting via videoconference in Moscow on Friday.

item.title: Middle East Sympathizes With Ukrainian Refugees
item.description: Many in the region took to social media to express sympathy for Ukrainians forced to flee, though their warm welcome in Europe evoked a tinge of bitterness over the treatment of Arab and Muslim migrants.
item.dc:creator: Mona El-Naggar
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A family from Ukraine arrives in Poland after crossing the border at Medyka on Saturday.

item.title: ‘No City in Ukraine Is Safe’: Family Escapes Missile Strike in Kyiv
item.description: After days in a bomb shelter, a family returned to their home in Kyiv for breakfast, and witnessed a missile strike on a neighboring apartment building.
item.dc:creator: Yousur Al-Hlou, Michael Downey and Masha Froliak
item.media:credit: Michael Downey for the New York Times

item.title: Find the C.D.C.'s New Pandemic Guidance for Your Area
item.description: The guidance is not binding, so local requirements may still apply. The federal mask requirement on mass transit and air travel is set to expire on March 18.
item.dc:creator: Sophie Downes
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: New York City in December, when the Omicron variant surge required safety measures like masks and social distancing. New guidance from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention allows U.S. counties to determine whether to skip pandemic measures. Some localities have already enabled such freedoms.

item.title: Demetrios Papademetriou, Top Immigration Scholar, Dies at 75
item.description: He designed the “Grand Bargain,” an ambitious plan for Mexican immigrants to gain legal status in the U.S., but it collapsed after the terrorist attacks of 9/11.
item.dc:creator: Katharine Q. Seelye
item.media:credit: Caroline Blumberg/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Demetrios Papademetriou at a conference in Paris in 2020. A founder of the Migration Policy Institute, he advised numerous governments about their immigration policies.

item.title: Ukrainian Civilians Arm Themselves to Fight the Russian Army in Kyiv
item.description: Civilian volunteers and paramilitary groups are taking the fight to the Russian army in Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Lynsey Addario
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian volunteers gather and prepare their weapons to fight Russian troops throughout Kyiv on Saturday.

item.title: Putin Faces Sanctions, but His Assets Remain an Enigma
item.description: On paper, the Russian president appears to own very little. Yet estimates put his hidden wealth well over $100 billion.
item.dc:creator: Mike McIntire and Michael Forsythe
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia at the G20 summit in Osaka, Japan, in 2019. He is facing sanctions from the United States and its European allies.

item.title: Big tech is betting that offices are still the future.
item.dc:creator: Kellen Browning
item.media:credit: Adam Riding for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Watermark office building at the edge of Tempe Town Lake, Ariz., is home to WeWork, Robinhood and some Amazon employees.

item.title: Russia Advances on 3 Ukrainian Cities, but Meets Fierce Resistance
item.description: Ukraine’s leader said his forces had “repelled” the Russian army’s assault. Moscow claimed it had merely “paused” for the possibility of peace negotiations.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins, Eric Schmitt, Michael Levenson and The New York Times
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Julia, a teacher and Ukrainian volunteer fighter, wept for her country as she waited to be deployed around Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital, on Saturday.

item.title: Biden and Putin, Children of the Cold War, Face Off Over Ukraine
item.description: Not since John F. Kennedy and Nikita S. Khrushchev confronted each other over Berlin and Cuba have an American president and Russian leader gone eyeball to eyeball in quite such a dramatic fashion.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:credit: Alexander Zemlianichenko/Associated Press
item.media:description: Vladimir V. Putin, left, and Joseph R. Biden Jr., right, back to camera, met in Moscow in 2011 when Mr. Putin was prime minister and Mr. Biden was vice president. Both leaders rose to power along distinct paths.

item.title: The C.D.C. releases new masking guidance and Queen Elizabeth tests positive: The week in Covid news.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:credit: Brittainy Newman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Exiting Penn Station in New York last week.

item.title: Volodymyr Zelensky Tries to Rally His People as Battle for Kyiv Rages
item.description: “We have withstood and successfully repelled enemy attacks,” President Volodymyr Zelensky said in the video. “The fighting continues in many cities and districts of our state, but we know that we protect the country, the land, the future of children.”
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Ukranian Presidential Press Service via Reuters

item.title: For Ukraine’s Refugees, Europe Opens Doors That Were Shut to Others
item.description: Thousands of Ukrainians will end up in countries led by nationalist governments that have been reluctant to welcome refugees in the past.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: Olha Zapotochna and her 3-year-old son, Arthur, after crossing the border from Ukraine into Poland on Friday.

item.title: The Comforts of Nostalgia
item.description: Popular culture is taking us back to the past.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Ukrainian forces slow Russian advance as the U.S. and its allies take action on Russian banks.
